div.head: To the READER.
div.p:
I Have for thy further information in the things of Chri≈øt, publi≈øhed an An≈øwer to ≈øome counter Queries, which were made by an unknown Author, in the behalf of Mr. Tho. Willes his Doctrine concerning the ≈øinfulne≈øs of Preaching without Ordination; in which counter-Queries, thou mai≈øt be acquainted with the Author's Spirit, though by his concealing his Name, thou can≈øt not be acquainted with his Per≈øon; and by a ≈øtrict Ob≈øervation of what he hath writ, thou mai≈øt ≈øee that he hath made good his own words, viz. That he had writ enough to puzzle, See his book page 4.

Act. 18. and by and by he ≈øaith, That it is certain, Apollos was at this time an Officer; and bids me prove, that he was ever made an Officer after his preaching, Act. 18. Again, he ≈øaith, If the Church of Rome was a true Church, then her Mini≈øters were true Mini≈øters, when our Reformers were ordained by her. And demands, why I did not di≈øprove her to be a Church, pag. 41. and yet a little before he ≈øaith, That ≈øhe was as bad when the Mini≈øters did receive Ordination from her, as ≈øhe was when they left her; and yet he ≈øaith, They left her not as ≈øhe was the Spou≈øe of Chri≈øt, but as ≈øhe was a Harlot, page 39. ≈øo that he ≈øuppo≈øeth Rome to be a Harlot, and Chri≈øt's Spou≈øe at one and the ≈øame time. Again, he ≈øaith, page 37. That the corruptions of the corrupt Di≈øpen≈øers of Ordinances cannot make them null; and yet he ≈øaith, pag. 48. If it be true as Mr. Brookes ≈øaith, That the Mini≈øters of England are Antichri≈øtian; then all that they have baptized, mu≈øt be baptized again. Is not this plain contradiction?

As he abounds with Contradictions, ≈øo he doth with Impertinencies, medling with the Trade that I follow, and my being a Souldier, and ≈øuch-like things, that concern not the Que≈øtion before him. Another while he blames me for that he doth him≈øelf, viz. of meddling with this Controver≈øie, and taking it out of Mr. Brookes his hand; when he undertook to an≈øwer a particular Paper, which was proper for none el≈øe to an≈øwer but Mr. Willes.

Another while he blames me for that I did charge a thing upon Mr. Willes, that I had but one witne≈øs for; and
yet him≈øelf believes the Accu≈øed's bare Negation without any witne≈øs: for at that time when Mr. VVilles de≈øired a Gentleman to apprehend me for a Je≈øuite, there was none pre≈øent to witne≈øs be≈øides the Gentleman afore≈øaid, though at our fir≈øt meeting there was divers.
Again, one while he ≈øaith, Rome had power to ordain Mini≈øters as Chri≈øt's Church; and by and by compares them to Thieves, and to Korah, at the time they ordained the fir≈øt Reformers.

Again, his Book is full of unman-like arguings, as appears by his frequent begging the chief things in que≈øtion; otherwhile, when I demand a proof of tho≈øe things that are ≈øo frequently affirmed by Mr. VVilles, he demands how I prove they are not; and ≈øo turns the proof of the affirmation from him≈øelf, and puts his Re≈øpondent to prove Negations. Surely, this is not to give a Rea≈øon of our Hope to every one that asketh, with Meekne≈øs and Fear.

Again, he tells his Reader, That the Anabapti≈øts are bloody, pag. 31. and pag. 50. he ≈øaith, he ghe≈ø≈øes, that they are the men who≈øe hands were mo≈øt embrued in the blood of the late VVars: When indeed, the Anabapti≈øts were in no capacity at the beginning of the≈øe Wars, to blow tho≈øe ≈øparks of contention into a burning Flame, if they had had a minde to ≈øo bad a work.

Thus I have given thee a ta≈øte of that Spirit that in≈øpired him in the writing of his Book, to which I have given an An≈øwer; and though I have not an≈øwered to every word, yet I have an≈øwered every thing that hath any ≈øhew or colour of Rea≈øon in it, which I de≈øire thee

div.head: Confidence encountred, &c.
div.p: ACcording to your de≈øire, I have an≈øwered your Counter Queries you ≈øent to me with a Letter; and though you have medled with a matter that concerns you not, yet know, that it concerns me to an≈øwer you, le≈øt you ≈øhould be confirmed in your folly: and though you contemn my Queries, as ≈ølight, and call me an unworthy Enemy, yet I have learned to ≈øay,

q.l: To ≈øcorn a Fool's contempt, is prai≈øe; and I,
His ≈øcorn, to be di≈øgrace, do quite deny.

div.p:
And though you thought you had ≈øo routed me, that I would never appear again; yet know, that this was nothing but the violent beatings of the Waves and Billows of your ambition, which I thought nece≈ø≈øary to put a check to, by this
en≈øuing An≈øwer, le≈øt you ≈øhould be exalted above mea≈øure: for the prevention whereof, I have publi≈øhed this Reply. And therein,

I Shall fir≈øt begin with your Title, wherein you call me a Confident Que≈øtioni≈øt: but if you had read my Epi≈øtle, you would have found, that I did que≈øtion, for Con≈øcience ≈øake, ≈øome things that Mr. Willes had delivered; and withal, did propound to the Reader, that if the An≈øwers thereunto did ≈øatisfie, I ≈øhould ble≈øs the Father of Lights that had not ≈øuffered me to labour in vain. This was the greate≈øt altitude of my Confidence, and the heighth of my Ambition in that undertaking.

You proceed to an Epi≈øtle, where you tell your Reader, That if he be a Friend to Truth, he probably hath ere this been grieved to ≈øee the ho≈øt of I≈ørael routed, &c. and the Mini≈øtery SO MUCH ≈øhattered, &c. why then do you glory and cry victoria, if the Clergy, which you call the Ho≈øt of I≈ørael, be routed? ≈øhould not you mourn, as well as you would have your Reader? but in ≈øtead thereof, you blame your Enemy for glorying, as though he had no occa≈øion; and wear the Lawrel your ≈øelf, wreathing it upon your own brows, as though you had ≈øo routed your Enemy, that he would never rally: what need is there for the Reader to grieve, if Mr. Willes hath routed and ≈øhattered the choice≈øt Ranks of his Enemies? (unle≈øs you flatter Mr. Willes, and deal truely with your Reader) for is not this ≈øtrange, that you tell your Reader,See his Epi≈øtle to Mr. Willes.
the Lords Ho≈øt is routed; and yet flatter with Mr. Willes, and tell him, the Enemy is routed? And by this you may ≈øee, that you are ≈øo unfit to be an Armour-Bearer in this Warfare, that you ju≈øtly de≈øerve to be cha≈øhiered the Camp for your fal≈øe Intelligence. For you tell Mr. Willes, the Enemy is ≈øhattered; and yet tell your Reader the Mini≈øtery are ≈øhattered. But is the Clergy ≈øhattered? no marvel then that the people are ≈øhattered: for, like Prie≈øt, like People: a ≈øhattered Clergy mu≈øt not look
for any thing, but a di≈øcompo≈øed people. And truely, that is the greate≈øt Truth in your Packet: for how few of them agree in any thing ≈øave in the point of Tythes, common experience can te≈øtifie, if you had ≈øaid nothing.

You go on ≈øtill in your Epi≈øtle, and tell your Reader, That if he be ≈øhaken, you have ≈øent him ≈øome Counter-Queries, and bid him judge, and try; and then (you ≈øay) you hope he will blu≈øh at his uncon≈øtancy, &c. So he may well, if what you have writ ≈øhould ≈øhake his under≈øtanding, then he mu≈øt needs be one that is carried about with every Airy notion.

You further tell your Reader, That if he be an enemy to truth, he hath triumphed before the victory, &c. How can that be? when you exhort to grieve, becau≈øe them that you call the Enemy, have routed the Ho≈øt: what is that le≈øs then Victory, if you ≈øpeak Truth?

You go on, and tell your Reader, That if Mr. Brookes or his Church, invited me to be the Patron of their cau≈øe, you might gue≈øs them to be mi≈øerably baffled, &c. Fir≈øt, neither Mr. Brookes nor his Church ever invited me to do them this ≈øervice; but if they had, if their inviting me to be a Patron to the cau≈øe, had argued them to be mi≈øerably baffled; how mi≈øerably baffled did you fear your ≈øelf ≈øhould be in what you had writ, when you begged Mr. Willes to be your Patron?

You tell your Reader, That he cannot expect Mr. Willes ≈øhould hinder his more ≈øerious di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of this weighty point, to take notice of my ≈ølight Queries. This, I confe≈øs, is an ea≈øie way to confute the ≈øtronge≈øt Arguments, for a man that is contrary minded, to call them ≈ølight; and ≈øay, he is not at lea≈øure to an≈øwer them. If I had an≈øwered you thus, ≈øurely men would have judged, you had more ≈øtrength on your ≈øide, then you have.

You go on, and bid your Reader ≈øee, if here be not enough to puzzle me, &c. You are now guilty of that which you blamed your Adver≈øary for, but now, viz. of triumphing before the Victory: but it ≈øeems then, the end of your writing was to puzzle, and not to convince your Adver≈øary.

I proceed now to take notice of your Epi≈øtle to Mr. Willes, in which you tell him, my grounds are ≈ølight, &c. This triumphing of yours, is but like that which Job ≈øpeaks of, that is but for a moment, Job 20.5.

You demand of Mr. Willes, in what ≈øence he a≈ø≈øerted the baptizing the Children of wicked Parents, &c. and you pre≈øume he means onely ≈øuch as are Church-Members, and are not ca≈øt out, &c. Truely, either your Church are all good, or el≈øe you are partakers of their ≈øins in not ca≈øting them out: for I have not heard of one vile per≈øon, that the Presbyters have excluded.

There is another Que≈øtion which you propound to Mr. Willes, viz What were his own words concerning the Fifth-Monarchy-men. About Mr. Willes a≈ø≈øerting tho≈øe words touching the Fifth-Monarchy-men, I have not wronged him, as hereafter ≈øhall appear.

You further ask Mr. Willes, Whether he did po≈øitively a≈ø≈øert me to be a Je≈øuite, &c. Surely, you did not think Mr. Willes had ≈øo much to do as you made your Reader believe even now, that you ask him ≈øo needle≈øs a Que≈øtion: for did I ≈øay or intimate that Mr. Willes did po≈øitively a≈ø≈øert me to be a Je≈øuite? why did you not ask him whether I had two hands or three? it had been as much to your purpo≈øe. But to proceed.

You tell him, That if any thing appear in print in an≈øwer to the whole, it will beg his patronage of its cau≈øe, &c. If he did not father it, it would be an Orphan, ≈øince the true Father will not be known. But doth not your Logick teach me to believe you feared to be mi≈øerably baffled, ≈øince you thus beg for his Patronage? Surely, you thought your Wine to be mix'd with Water, that you beg Mr. Willes his Bu≈øh to hang at your Door, that ≈øo it might ≈øell the better, and not be que≈øtioned.

The next thing that followeth in your Book is Mr. Willes his Letter, wherein he tells you, That the people were ≈øo rude
that it might have proved to my peril, if he had not pacified them, &c. This ≈øhews what Spirit your Churches are filled withal, that it is perillous for a man to ask a Que≈øtion among them, though never ≈øo ≈øoberly: for no man in his wits will believe that they were of Mr. Brookes his Church that were ≈øo much my Enemies, ≈øeeing (you ≈øay) I came to be a Patron to their cau≈øe.
Mr. Willes tells you further, That he laid down two Principles, as the grounds of my ≈øatisfaction:

list.item: 1. That Mini≈øters in an ordinary way were to be ordained by Mini≈øters.
2. That in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, where there was no Mini≈øters to ordain, fit Per≈øons might become Mini≈øters without Ordination, &c.

div.p: But he doth not tell you, that I asked him by which of the≈øe ways he came into the Mini≈øtery; and he would not tell me, though I pre≈øt him once and again: for though I grant the≈øe two ways of Admi≈ø≈øion, yet I denied that ever he came in by either. Hereupon he told me, If there was but two ways of coming into a Hou≈øe, and if he were in, I mu≈øt conclude that he came in at one of them. But is not this a ≈øhameful begging the Que≈øtion? for though I granted the≈øe two were to be the ways of entrance, yet I denied him to be come in by either. Now what is it but to beg the Que≈øtion, when he ≈øhall take it for granted he is in by one of the afore≈øaid ways, when I denied him to be in by either? as him≈øelf confe≈ø≈øeth in his Letter to you, pag. 7. later end: for he ≈øaith, I oppo≈øed both; meaning both his entrance by a lawful Ordination, or by nece≈ø≈øity. So then, this is your Champion's Argument, which is like Goliah's Sword in his hand, the Propo≈øition being, That he is no Mini≈øter of Chri≈øt, either by a lawful Ordination, or by any pretended nece≈ø≈øity: So that his great Argument (if I may put it in form) is:

q.l: If I am a Mini≈øter by one of the≈øe ways, then I am a Mini≈øter by one of them:
But I am a Mini≈øter by one of them;
Ergo, I am a Mini≈øter by one of them.

div.p: Nothing el≈øe can be made of this that he propounds. Now this had been a dilemma indeed, if I had granted him to be a true Mini≈øter, and had confe≈ø≈øed that a man cannot be a true Mini≈øter but by one of the ways afore≈øaid; then he had rea≈øoned like a man, if he had ≈øaid, Since I grant him to be a Mini≈øter, and withal grant, that none can enter but by the ways afore≈øaid, then he mu≈øt needs come in by one of them. But ≈øince I denied both, how wildly doth he rea≈øon?

Again, doth not Chri≈øt ≈øay, That he that comes not in at the door, is a thief and a robber? Now though I granted that there was no other lawful way of coming into the Office, yet a mans being in, doth not prove he came in any of the≈øe lawful ways; becau≈øe Chri≈øt ≈øuppo≈øeth they may get in by climing up another way.

The next thing Mr. Willes takes notice of in his An≈øwer to your Letter, is that which he ≈øpake about the baptizing the Children of wicked Parents, which he ≈øaith are ≈øuch Children, who≈øe Parents are not juridically ejected by excommunication, &c.

His Reformation, as I have told, is ≈øo good, that none de≈øerves Excommunication; or el≈øe ≈øo bad, that he doth not execute that Ordinance upon them; or if he do, then all that he doth excommunicate are childle≈øs; or el≈øe he, contrarily to his Principles, baptizeth their Children; for he refu≈øeth to baptize none. But if his Argument be good, That the Children of wicked Parents are to be baptized, becau≈øe ≈øometimes God chu≈øeth them that are wicked Mens Children, Doth not this Argument plead as much for the Children of tho≈øe that are excommunicated? may not God chu≈øe the Children of ≈øuch as well the Children of others? and doth
not the Children of wicked excommunicated Parents, ≈øtand in need of an Obligation to Holine≈øs, as well as the Children of tho≈øe wicked Parents that are not excommunicated? and yet this man ≈øaith, That wicked mens Children, the wor≈øe their Parents are, the more need their Children have of Bapti≈øm: and yet he denies it to the children of tho≈øe who are excommunicated. It ≈øeems then, you judge them you keep in the Church wor≈øe then they you ca≈øt out, or el≈øe this cannot be a true Maxime, viz. The wor≈øe the Parents are, the more need the Children have of Bapti≈øm: for if they you ca≈øt out are the wor≈øt, then it follows, that their Children have the more need, by his Argument: if ≈øo, why doth he confine it to none but ≈øuch as are within the Church?

Whoever de≈øires further ≈øatisfaction in this point, touching the baptizing of Infants. I ≈øhall refer them to my Book, entituled, Infants Bapti≈øm di≈øproved; by which you will ≈øee Mr. Willes his fal≈øe A≈øper≈øion wiped away, viz. That I ≈øought to colour my Opinion, which was again≈øt the Baptizing of any infants. For not onely my Book te≈øtifies my willingne≈øs to own my Opinion publickly, but I did tell Mr. Willes to his Face, that I would prove it unlawful to baptize any Infant; as many can witne≈øs.

Mr. Willes in his Letter further tells you, That he did decry the Fifth-Monarchy-men among other Sects that cry down their Mini≈øtery, as the ≈ømoak of the bottomle≈øs pit, ≈ømelling ≈øtrong of the Brim≈øtone of Hell: his proof for this is ≈øo faint, that he ≈øu≈øpects it him≈øelf; for he ≈øaith, he alluded in that ≈øpeech to Rev. 9.2, 3. by which text (he ≈øaith) ≈øuch Sects are meant, AS SOME DO INTERPRET. Is not this a brave ≈øtroke? do you reckon this one of his fatal blows he hath given the Adver≈øary, by telling them their Breath is as the ≈ømoak of the bottomle≈øs Pit? but it is but AS SOME DO INTERPRET.

div.p: The la≈øt thing of moment that Mr. Willes mentions in his Letter, is, That he never affirmed upon any information that I was a Je≈øuite; and that he did never in≈øtigate any to apprehend mt. For proof of this, I ≈øhall refer you to this Gentleman, Mr. Vancourt for a Witne≈øs, who is ready to make Oath of the truth thereof; by which Mr. Willes his untruths appear, together with his malice, though he cries out of the malice of others.

This Gentleman is a man known for Piety, and to bear a good e≈øteem in the National Mini≈øtery; and al≈øo he is of good Credit in the World: and therefore know, that it was more ju≈øt for me to believe his Affirmation, then for you to take the Accu≈øed's bare Negation. Therefore I judge, my life would lie at ≈øtake, if Mr. Willes had as good proof to prove me a Je≈øuite, as I have to prove that he did adverti≈øe this Gentleman to apprehend me for a Je≈øuite.
This ≈øhall ≈øuffice to this Letter, and to your ob≈øervation thereon in the later end of your Book.

I come now to your Epi≈øtle Dedicatory, wherein you do excu≈øe your flattering of Mr. Willes: but what do you el≈øe, when you tell him you pre≈øume to be his Armor-Bearer? and in a Complement tell him, That you were a ≈øpectator of tho≈øe furious ≈øtrokes, whereby he ≈øhattered the choi≈øe≈øt Ranks of his Enemies, and dealt about ≈øuch fatal blows, that their choi≈øe≈øt Champions fell before him, &c.

So then it appears by your own grant, That ≈øhe was none of Chri≈øt's Spou≈øe or Church at the time ≈øhe did ordain your Predece≈ø≈øors: for you ≈øay, She was a Harlot when you left her; and then you ≈øay, She was as hone≈øt as when your Predece≈ø≈øors were ordained by her.

Is it not a ≈øhame then, that you ≈øhould ≈øay, That you are Legitimate? when afer you have taken pains to prove it, you face about, as though it were too hard a Task for you, and in words at length call your Mother a Where: for what do you le≈øs, when you call her a Harlot? in pag. 39. at the beginning of it. Is not this madne≈øs to a great degree, that you ≈øhould ≈øay, Rome was none of Chri≈øt's Spou≈øe, but a Harlot; and yet labour to prove, (if you could) That at this time in the midde≈øt of her Whoredoms, ≈øhe had power to ordain Mini≈øters to preach Chri≈øt? Pray tell me, why any man might not have taken upon him to ordain, as well
as Rome, if this be true that you ≈øay. Did ever our Lord Chri≈øt give the power of Ordination of Mini≈øters to any but his Spou≈øe or Church, whereof he is the Head? and when≈øoever ≈øhe ≈øhall turn Whore, and pro≈øtitute her ≈øelf to other Lovers, hath ≈øhe not lo≈øt this Power and Authority? is ≈øhe not then like un≈øavoury Salt, fit for nothing? and yet by your Logick, ≈øhe hath Authority from Chri≈øt to ordain Mini≈øters to preach the Go≈øpel.
This very ≈øaying of yours, viz. That your Mother, the Church of Rome, was a Whore at the time your Predece≈ø≈øors were ordained by her, confutes all your conceits of a lawful Succe≈ø≈øion.

Que≈øt. 29 I proceed to the twenty ninth Que≈øtion, where I demand, If all the Mini≈øters that were in England before Austin the Monk, were not brought into communion with the Roman-Church? And this was the ≈øum of that Que≈øtion.

To which you make no an≈øwer; but in effect ask me the ≈øame thing over again, viz. Whether Gildas doth not report of a Mini≈øtery in England, before Au≈øtin the Monk? &c. and Whether there might not remain thou≈øands that had not bowed their knee to Baal, and we not know of it?

To this I an≈øwer, That then your Mini≈øtery could not be derived from the Briti≈øh Succe≈ø≈øion, if you did not know whether they did bow their knee or no. But if what you ≈øaid before was true, That the Church of Rome had a power to ordain in the mid≈øt of their pollutions, then it is no great matter whether they did bow to Baal or no, as to the matter in que≈øtion, ≈øeeing that if they had, by your Logick, it could not have hindred your lawful Succe≈ø≈øion, from them.

Que≈øt. 30 To my thirtieth Que≈øtion, which demands, Whether there was in England a Succe≈ø≈øion of a true Church, ≈øeparated from Rome, all the time the Papal Power was exerci≈øed here? and how it did appear, That the Succe≈ø≈øion of the Mini≈øtery of England, was from this reformed, rather then the Papal Line?
You an≈øwer as before, That there might be a Succe≈ø≈øion, though we know not of it, &c.

This being the ≈øame with the former, let the ≈øame An≈øwer ≈øuffice; onely let me tell you, That it is very improbable, that a Church ≈øhould remain in England in oppo≈øition to Rome, all the time the Papal Power was here,Witne≈øs tho≈øe that were ≈ølain at Bangor. ≈øince Au≈øtin the Monk by force and arms was re≈øtle≈øs in ≈øubjecting the Britains in all parts to the See of Rome.

Que≈øt. 31 I proceed to the next Que≈øtion, which doth demand, Whether it was not a ≈øin to leave Rome as a Cage of every unclean thing, if ≈øhe was entru≈øted with the Admini≈øtration of Chri≈øt's Ordinances, as a Church, &c. This was the ≈øub≈øtance of the Que≈øtion.
Upon which you query, Whether ≈øhe may not be a Cage of every unclean thing, and yet have Gods ≈øacred Ordinances among them?

This is the ≈øum of your Que≈øtion, unto which you would give light by ≈øeveral ≈øimilitudes: one is, That if a Thief have a Bible in his pocket, he is notwith≈øtanding a Thief, Hence you would infer, That Rome may be po≈ø≈øe≈øt with Gods Ordinances, though they are Thieves.

But have you forgot your ≈øelf? did not you ≈øay, That the receiver was as bad as the thief? pag. 21. Now then, if this be true, do you not very craftily call the Clergy Thieves? for they all (you ≈øay) did receive their Ordination from them.
You further ≈øay, That the cen≈øers Corah burned incen≈øe in, were the Lords, &c.
Hence you would innfer, That Ordination is Gods Ordinance, though it be in the hands of unholy per≈øons, &c.

To which I an≈øwer, That the Ordinances are God's, as the Cen≈øers were; but as Korah did wickedly in u≈øing them, ≈øo did the Company that partook with him; and it was not their crying out, That the cen≈øers were holy, that would excu≈øe them: ≈øo it is not your ≈øaying, That Ordination of Mini≈øters is a holy Ordinance, that will excu≈øe Apo≈øtates
in admini≈øtring of it, or you in receiving ≈øuch Admini≈øtration.

Remember therefore this example of Korah, and do not you partake of Korah's ≈øin; for though the Cen≈øers were holy, he had no right to u≈øe them: ≈øee therefore how this ≈øimilitude makes again≈øt you, and fully ≈øhews your vanity, that all you glory in, is but what you have received from a Korah, a Thief, a Harlot, which had no more right to admini≈øter it, then a Thief hath to di≈øtribute ≈øtolen Goods.
Que≈øt. 32 I demanded in the next place, How Rome being the Cage of every unclean thing, could admini≈øter ≈øo ≈øacred an Ordinance, as ordaining Go≈øpel-Mini≈øters? &c.

You ≈øay nothing in your Counter-Query, but what hath been ≈øaid before; onely you urge a fre≈øh ≈øimilitude that is nothing to your purpo≈øe, viz. That if my Accounts that be in my Book be ju≈øt and right, they ought not to be nulled, becau≈øe my boy hath naughtily written them, &c.
Hence you would infer, That Ordination is Gods Ordinance, though it hath been defaced by the Church of Romes uncleanne≈øs, &c.

Which is not any part of my Que≈øtion: for though my Accounts are not to be di≈øowned becau≈øe my boy hath blotted them, yet my boy hath not power to di≈øpo≈øe of them acording to his invention: neither is it lawful for you, if I ≈øhall declare him to be a Thief, to receive any of my money from him, or take any di≈øcharge or acquittance for any debt that you owe me, at his hand. In like manner is it ≈øinful to receive Ordination from Rome: if they have turned Thieves and Robbers, as you ≈øay they are , then the Receiver is as bad as the Thief. So that I ≈øhall need no other weapon to fight with you then your own. But to proceed, I come now,

Que≈øt. 33 To the thirty third Que≈øtion, wherein I demand, If the Church of Rome had power as a Church, and you did ≈øeparate becau≈øe of her corruptions, why then was Mr.
Brooks to be blamed in ≈øeparating from the corruption of the Church of England? &c.

In your many-headed Counter-Query, you ≈øay nothing that concerns me to an≈øwer; but this, viz, That becau≈øe I ≈øay, If Rome was a true Church, &c. Hence you glory, and ≈øay, I yield up my weapons, by ≈øaying, IF Rome was a true Church.
You demand then, To what end was all my other Que≈øtions? &c.

I an≈øwer, That you had need go to School to learn to di≈øtingui≈øh between an Hypothetical and a Categorical Propo≈øition: for is it not one thing to ≈øay, The Church of Rome IS a true Church; and another thing to ≈øay, IF ≈øhe be a true Church? Might you not as well have told your Reader, That David ≈øaid, He COULD take the Wings of the Morning, and flie, becau≈øe he ≈øaid, IF I take the wings of the morning, &c.

This is the ground of your triumph; becau≈øe I ≈øay, If Rome was a true Church; you conclude I ≈øaid, She was a ture Church. O brave Logician! I ≈øee now there was a rea≈øon why you concealed your Name.

And for tho≈øe other que≈øtions that you ask me concerning Mr. Brooks his ≈øeparation, in p. 41, 42. I ≈øhall refer you to him, who very likely can give you a better An≈øwer then you have given to my Queries.
Que≈øt. 34 I demand in the next place, Why the Prote≈øtant Shepherds ≈øhear the Papi≈øts, ≈øince they judge them no Sheep of their fold? This is the ≈øum of the Que≈øtion.
In your Reply, you ≈øay little that concerns me to an≈øwer; onely, That the Church hath debarred Papi≈øts from communion.
And thereupon you demand, Whether it be not rea≈øon then, that they ≈øhould pay their tythes? &c.

To this I an≈øwer, That there is little rea≈øon why any
body ≈øhould pay; but there is le≈øs rea≈øon why one that is put out of the Fold ≈øhould pay, then any: nay, there is no colour of rea≈øon, why any that are ca≈øt out of the Church ≈øhould be forced to maintain the Mini≈øter. Should not you have done well to have proved this, before you went further? viz. That Chri≈øt would have men pay tythes to a Mini≈øter when they are thru≈øt out of their ≈øtock, and are put out of communion?

The re≈øt of this Que≈øtion which you ask, relates to Mr. Brooks his practice, of which I have not ≈øo particular an information, as an an≈øwer to it requires; and therefore I ≈øhall refer you to him for an An≈øwer.

Que≈øt. 35 I demand in the next place, Whether that the rea≈øon why you do exclude Papi≈øts, which is becau≈øe they do not reform, be not the rea≈øon why Mr. Brooks excludes ≈øcandalous per≈øons, viz. becau≈øe they do not reform? &c.
Your An≈øwer hereunto, (as far as it doth concern me) is, That Mr. Brooks keeps people out of his Church, becau≈øe they do not own his Church, and di≈øown their own.

To this I an≈øwer, That this is the rea≈øon why you reject Papi≈øts: for many of them are ≈øuch, who≈øe lives are without reproof; ≈øo that you keep them out, becau≈øe they will not own your Church, and di≈øown their own.

Que≈øt. 36 Your query upon my thirty ≈øixth Que≈øtion, is nothing but what hath been queried by you before, and is already an≈øwered, both in my An≈øwer to M. Willes his Letter, in the beginning of this Book, and al≈øo in my Reply to the twenty ≈øixth Counter-Query.
Que≈øt. 37 I query, ≈øince Ordination from Rome was thrown off upon a politick account, what ground the Mini≈øters of the Nation have to plead a nece≈ø≈øity to preach without Ordination.

The ≈øub≈øtance of your Counter-Query to this, as it relates to your Succe≈ø≈øion, is an≈øwered already in the thirty
≈øixth Query: and for that part of your que≈øtion that relates to nece≈ø≈øity, I an≈øwer,
Fir≈øt, That there was no need of our fir≈øt Reformers pleading nece≈ø≈øity; for they were as idolatrous when they fir≈øt rent from Rome, as they were when they were in communion with her.

Secondly, If they had ≈øeparated from the Church of Rome, becau≈øe of her uncleanne≈øs, then there was no need for them to plead nece≈ø≈øity for their preaching without Ordination, ≈øince they might have been ordained by the reformed Churches in other Countries, which had for≈øaken Rome before them.

And thirdly, if Nece≈ø≈øity may be a Warrant to them at that time, it was as good a Warrant to other Sects that revolted from Rome, as well as it was for tho≈øe you call our fir≈øt Reformers. So that then, if any Arrians or Socinians, &c. ≈øhould have Rent from Rome, and gathered into a Congregation, they might have pleaded that they had a lawful Mini≈øtery, either by Succe≈ø≈øion, in that ≈øome of them had been Prie≈øts before they revolted; or el≈øe by vertue of a Nece≈ø≈øity, ≈øince a po≈øitive Law gives place to nece≈ø≈øity. Would not you an≈øwer the≈øe men, that they are Mini≈øters by neither of the≈øe ways? and ≈øo do I an≈øwer you, as I have already done once and again.

And therefore, when Mr. Willes hath proved him≈øelf a lawful Mini≈øter, then I ≈øhall ≈øay, He came in by one of the≈øe ways: but till then, let me tell him, and you too, That any Sect that will take it for granted, that they have Mini≈øters among them, may as well ju≈øtifie their Mini≈øters Authority, as Mr. Willes can do his, by taking it for granted he is a Mini≈øter of Chri≈øt, which he is never able to prove.
Que≈øt. 38 I demanded, When the Line of Succe≈ø≈øion was broke, whether then every one might not preach that were able, although it might not have been lawful before? &c.
This was the ≈øum of this Que≈øtion.

To which you ≈øay nothing but what hath been already an≈øwered over and over; onely you ask me, Whether a ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity makes any Mini≈øters but tho≈øe that are fitte≈øt, and undertake the charge.
To which I an≈øwer, That if the Men that preach ≈øhall be their own Judges, who will not think that he is fit and able?

And was it not ≈øo with tho≈øe you call our fir≈øt Reformers? were they not Judges of their own abilities, and ≈øo made them≈øelves Mini≈øters of their own heads? and by the ≈øame Rule, others may depart from them, as they departed from Rome; and take upon them to be Heads or Guides of a Congregation of people; e≈øpecially, if they can object con≈øiderable errors both in their Lives and Doctrines.
Que≈øt. 39 My next Que≈øtion demands, how it can be a ≈øin for any to preach that are able, ≈øeeing there is no Ordination on foot now, but what men take up by Nece≈ø≈øity, &c.
This is the ≈øub≈øtance of the que≈øtion.

To which you ≈øay nothing, but what hath been ≈øaid and an≈øwered; only you demand, Whether there may not be a lawful ≈øucce≈ø≈øion from tho≈øe that fir≈øt took upon them this Office by Nece≈ø≈øity? and whether any in an ordinary lawful way can be in office, but tho≈øe that have it from that ≈øucce≈ø≈øion? &c.

To this I an≈øwer, That if what you here ≈øuppo≈øe be true, then why did not our fir≈øt Reformers go to the Mini≈øters of other reformed Churches for Ordination, rather then take it from Mr. Scory, and that Faction? ≈øince there was divers reformed Churches where they might have been ordained without receiving it from Rome, or without putting them≈øelves into the Office upon a pretended nece≈ø≈øity.

So that if what you ≈øay be true, That there may be a lawful ≈øucce≈ø≈øion from tho≈øe, who fir≈øt became Officers by vertue of a nece≈ø≈øity, and that it is ≈øinful to pretend to nece≈ø≈øity afterwards; then our fir≈øt Reformers cannot plead Not Guilty, ≈øince (as I have ≈øaid) there was no nece≈ø≈øity for them to own an Ordination
from Rome, becau≈øe they might have have had it in more purity from tho≈øe you call the reformed Churches, which had ≈øeparated from the Church of Rome before England.

And ≈øecondly, There was no nece≈ø≈øity for them to become Officers whithout Ordination, no more then there is now, becau≈øe there were many reformed Churches in being, to which they might have applied them≈øelves for Ordination, as in France and Germany, &c.

La≈øtly, if there was no true Church in the world that had power to ordain our new Bi≈øhops; but they mu≈øt make u≈øe of that which they received from Rome, and that this be a lawful Ordination, as you confe≈øs; then you mu≈øt needs ≈øay, That the Churches of France, Germany, Geneva, Scotland, &c. were no true Churches, and had no true and lawful ≈øucce≈ø≈øion; or if they had been true reformed Churches, either by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion or nece≈ø≈øity, why then did not our fir≈øt Reformers go to ≈øome of the≈øe to be ordained? and ≈øince they did not, doth it not manife≈øtly appear, that they were not true Mini≈øters by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, becau≈øe they received Ordination from Rome, whom you call a Harlot, when they might have had it from the Mini≈øters of the reformed Churches then in being? and becau≈øe there was reformed Churches in being, where they might have been ordained, they had no rea≈øon to plead to any nece≈ø≈øity then of preaching without Ordination, any more then Mr. Brooks and others have, whom Mr. Willes and you condemn.

Que≈øt. 40 I come now to the fortieth Que≈øtion that I propounded, which demands what Ground Mr. Willes had to baptize the children of wicked parents? &c. And to this you ≈øay nothing but what I have an≈øwered already; only you beg a que≈øtion, viz. That children have a right to be members of a vi≈øible Church. Which when you have proved it, viz. That infants, while they are in infancy, have an immediate right to be members of a Church in the new Te≈øtament, I ≈øhall confe≈øs they may be baptized; but till then, I ≈øhall be again≈øt the baptizing any infant, for all you think I would conceal my Opinion in this matter.

Que≈øt. 41 In the next place I demand, Whether to baptize the children of wicked parents, be not contrary to the Opinion of the reformed Churches? You reply, That in the ≈øen≈øe M. Willes doth a≈ø≈øert the baptizing of the children of wicked parents, it is lawful. To which I an≈øwer, That I have replied to Mr. Willes his ≈øen≈øe about the baptizing the children of wicked parents, in my An≈øwer to his Letter, at the beginning of this Book. All that you ≈øay to this que≈øtion, be≈øides what I have an≈øwered, doth appertain to ≈øome practices of Mr. Brooks, which I ≈øhall not meddle with, becau≈øe I am not acquainted with them, only I take notice, that in p. 48. of your Book, before you end this que≈øtion, you ≈øay, That if the Mini≈øtery of England be Antichri≈øtian, then it will follow, that tho≈øe that they have baptized are unlawfully baptized, &c. How ≈øhamefully do you contradict your ≈øelf? did you not ≈øay before, That the corruptions of the di≈øpen≈øers of Ordinances could not make the Ordinances a nullity, though the Admini≈øtrator was Antichri≈øtian? And do you not now in effect ≈øay, That bapti≈øm is a nullity, if the Admini≈øtrator be Antichri≈øtian? for you ≈øay, If the National Mini≈øtery be Antichri≈øtian, (as Mr. Brooks ≈øaith) it will follow, that it is unlawful. Do you not now ju≈øtifie all that I have ≈øaid, viz. If the fir≈øt Reformers were ordained by Antichri≈øtian Mini≈øters, that then it followeth, that their Ordination is a nullity; and that till they are ordained again, they all of them preach without Ordination from Chri≈øt? Thus the Reader may ≈øee, that rather then you would want an arrow to ≈øhoot at M. Brooks, you would borrow one out of my quiver; and you do as good as confe≈øs as much, when you conclude, and ≈øay, That your heart trembleth, and you heartily wi≈øh, that you could not plead ≈øo ≈øtrongly, to ≈øadden hone≈øt hearts, to plea≈øe me, and ≈øuch as I am. It ≈øeems then, your con≈øcience told you, That you had given away your cau≈øe to the grief of your ≈øelf and others, becau≈øe you could not help it; and therefore you wi≈øh heartily, that you COULD not plead ≈øo much, to plea≈øe ≈øuch as I am. So that it ≈øeems, you are now forced to yield to your own grief and others of your friends, which you call hone≈øt hearts, &c. it ≈øeems then, the truth is too ≈øtrong for you. But to proceed.

You come now to make Counter-queries, upon my 42, 43, 44, and 45 Queries that are grounded upon Mr. Willes his decrying the Fifth-Monarchy-Men, as the ≈ømoak of the bottomle≈øs pit: to this I have already given an≈øwer. And to the Counter-queries you propound upon my 46 que≈øtion, touching Mr. Willes his Di≈øcour≈øe with me in private, I have already an≈øwered in my Reply to M. Willes his Letter.

And for your Counter-query that you make upon my 47 que≈øtion about Mr. Willes his per≈øwading a Gentleman to apprehend me for a Je≈øuite, though you ≈øay, I am too blame to receive an information from one man, &c. Sure you are more too blame to believe the Accu≈øed's bare negation: but for the truth of what I object again≈øt M. Willes, viz. That he did de≈øire a Gentleman to apprehend me for a Je≈øuite; I ≈øhall refer the Reader to the Gentleman aforenamed, who is ready to make oath for his further ≈øatisfaction.

And for your ≈øaying, That I did live a concealed life about London for many yeers; and therefore there might be ≈øome ground for people to ≈øu≈øpect me. Truely, I think there is more rea≈øon why I ≈øhould ≈øu≈øpect you, who are ≈øo concealed, as that you refu≈øe to let your Name or place of abode be known; I am ≈øure, this I never did upon any occa≈øion in all my life.
I come now to take notice of your Po≈øt≈øcript, wherein you tell your Reader of ≈øome things you have to adverti≈øe him.

The fir≈øt (you ≈øay) is, That it is a great ≈øign of truth, when men of corrupt mindes are enraged again≈øt it. Truely, then it is a ≈øign that we are in the truth; for men of corrupt mindes are again≈øt us, witne≈øs the rude behavior of tho≈øe that threatned to throw me over the Gallery for asking M. Willes a que≈øtion; and not onely tho≈øe, but ≈øuch as make a gain of godline≈øs, leaping from one benefice to another, where they can get the be≈øt fleece, and mo≈øt profit; and that without they can have their own demands of their Pari≈øh, they will leave them, and go to another. I ≈øay, the≈øe are the men that cry down that which we profe≈øs, as the ≈ømoak of the bottomle≈øs pit, and would have men apprehended as Je≈øuites, or any
how, ≈øo that they can be revenged upon them for not being of their Opinion: I ≈øay then, That if this may be called a good Argument, the Truth is of our ≈øide: but this is no infallible way of rea≈øoning. In the ≈øecond place, you tell your Reader, That tho≈øe that have de≈øigns again≈øt the truth, have u≈øually ≈øome plau≈øible pretence to carry them on, &c. To this I an≈øwer, That you are none of tho≈øe that have plau≈øible de≈øigns again≈øt the truth; though you have a great many, you have ≈øcarce one that is plau≈øible: for if you had, you would never have di≈øcovered to the world ≈øo much contradiction & folly, as you have done in your Book; neither would you have declared, That your Mother, the Church of Rome, was a Harlot at the time that your Predece≈ø≈øors received Ordination from her; neither would you have compared her to Korah, & to a Thief, as you have done; and yet ju≈øtifie her ordaining Mini≈øters to preach the Go≈øpel. Would you have had your de≈øigns plau≈øible, you ≈øhould never have di≈øcovered the Pedegree of your Clergy, by calling their Progenitors Thieves and Harlots: ≈øure this will not be plau≈øible to any that ≈øhall hear it, when they come to know, that your glorious ≈øucce≈ø≈øion you ≈øo much boa≈øt of, came from ≈øuch infamous Predece≈ø≈øors. The third thing you inform your Reader in, is, That tho≈øe that de≈øign the propagating of errors, will for the mo≈øt part oppo≈øe, but ≈øeldom a≈ø≈øert, &c. To this I reply, That this is the rea≈øon you an≈øwered by counter-queries; and that rather then you would a≈ø≈øert any thing po≈øitively, you put your re≈øpondent to prove negations; when the contrary was found in me: for I offered to a≈ø≈øert and prove again≈øt M. Willes, and he refu≈øed it. The la≈øt thing you inform your Reader, is, That this Book is your fir≈øt, &c. This you u≈øe as an argument why he ≈øhould excu≈øe your mi≈øtakes, &c. and truely, Sir, you had need of a pardon: and if you did not hope for it, you might fear to be corrected by a more ≈øevere hand then mine, for tho≈øe many impertinencies, ≈ølanders and contradictions that your Book is fraught withal; which I pray God help you to con≈øider of, that you may do nothing again≈øt the truth, but for it; which is the de≈øire of,
